user.biography:
| You are art, 
And art is everything. |
All content is my own, unless stated otherwise.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
When you've got friends like this, there's not a lot else you need. 

What a beautiful surprise. 

Made with ❤️ by Tallboi @abhisheknairofficial,
and alleged brainchild of @dr_popper_giri, 
I love you guys.
@cyanaidu you're the only one who didn't ask for credit but I know you're in the mix too hahah you know ily. 

@mockmyname I know you're swamped in the process of becoming one of the best surgeons I know you will turn to be, thank you for taking your time out to get your message to me. MKT5H forever. This wouldn't have been complete without your name on it. Ilee. 

@enthamarethi, Your art >>> 
absolutely made my day. I hear they chewed your ears off with ideas, so thank you for sticking with it and creating this for me on my birthday. 

To everyone else who sent messages/called with all your love, thank you so much. 
My heart is full.

Spoken Poetry today.
I've been deliberating on this for a while now but could never find the courage or comfort to put it up. 
But here goes, let me know how you like it, 
Honest feedbacks much appreciated 🤍
.
.
🔸
There's a field I walk on barefoot, unafraid of the dirt that clings to my skin because this is soil where feelings come to die, unsoiled, unsullied. 

I'm a mortician for the unclaimed performing final rites as I scrub away the blood from wounds unhealed and wrap it neatly beneath white sheets. There's a purity in death that washes away the taint of life, so I lay to rest that which I hope will remain unperturbed;
You who never found peace in your existence, 
May you rest easy in extinction. 

I dig up pits in the ground to resemble the pits in my stomach from which I gave birth to those I now bury beneath my feet before they ever learned to walk;
You who never learnt to take your first breath out of the womb,
May you never need another as you lay in your tomb. 

I say a prayer as I build a graveyard without headstones, without labels, without names;
You who was never recognised in life,
May you learn that remembrance serves you no purpose in death. 

There are poems I write, 
unafraid of the ink that stains my skin because this is ink where feelings come to drown;
I recite them like a prayer, 
You ask me why I write, 
I tell you ,
"To bury dead parts of me so that I may live just right.
🔸 
. 
.
@silverleafpoetry @bleedingsoulpoetry @streetwritersofficial 
@unerasepoetry 
@poemsindia 
@evepoetrygroup

Happy birthday to the biggest torture, and the no. 1 woman in my life ♥️
Please don't beat me again. (Subtitles already in for all my non Mallu friends dw I got you)
.
.
.
.
.
.
#mandontdance
#manmaycook 
#pleaselaugh
#donthurtmyfeelings 
#cookingathome
#dancingathome 
#whynotdobothatthesametime
#lifeunderlockdown

node.text:
[Swipe to Read] ⏩
🔹
Came across this story recently and just had to write. 
Leaving the relevant history below.
🔹
The first part of Anne's story is cast in shadow and not much is known about her. 
We know her now as Anne, but in the 1880s, when her body was recovered from the River Seine, the French knew her as “L’Inconnue de la Seine” (“The Unknown Woman of the Seine”).
Her body showed no signs of physical injury and the death was considered a suicide. 

As was practice then, the body was put on public display to be identified at the Paris morgue. However, despite the crowd, her identity was never verified. 
A mortician working at the morgue, captivated by her serene beauty, ordered a plaster cast of her face. A copy of this mask was hung outside a Paris shop sparking a public fascination with the girl’s enchanting final expression. 

Countless copies of this mask would then be created, and become highly coveted as a work of art, gracing the walls of homes and businesses in Europe. 
And the mysterious circumstances revolving around her death would become a muse for writers and poets - countless tales of a heartbroken girl, bereft of love and fortune, casting her life away in a romantic death by drowning. 

Over half a century later, in 1960, a group of doctors perfected a new life-saving technique called cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). To properly train individuals in this revolutionary new technique the doctors determined a special training doll was needed.
They partnered with the Norwegian toy and medical device manufacturer, Asmund Laerdal. Having witnessed first hand the benefits of CPR, a few years earlier when his 2 year old son nearly drowned,
He was a strong believer in the cause. 

The doctors wanted the mannequin to be female. They feared their life-saving technique would be withheld from women by men uncomfortable with performing CPR on the opposite sex. By having men practice on a female doll it was hoped they would overcome their inhibition and render the life-saving aid.
Laerdal would then use the face of L'inconnue, inspired by a copy that hung in his parents' home. 
.
.
[Continued in comments] 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on March 06, 2021 tagging @silverleafpoetry, @scribblersword, @globalagepoetry, @globalagecaption, and @brownhourpoetry. May be an image of text that says 'Annie, are we okay?: You and we're two strangers in love, Fighting for our stars to cross paths, But we 're born out of different galaxies. They tell me I'm setting myself up for a heartbreak, They ask me why I'd do this. What insanity in heaven's name would ever make me willingly accept this predicament, And all ever did, All /could ever do, Was whisper your name.'.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on March 06, 2021 tagging @thewritingspook, @profound.artists, @_inkverse, @thewriteristichutofficial, and @wovenverses. May be an image of text that says 'Love always came easy to me, It takes root in me and flourishes ceaselessly till it bears fruit. But one bite of it and you'll learn that For every sweet scented flower which Grows unchecked in the hollow of my neck, I bear salt laden pomes that lace your lips With my tears so heavy, you wouldn't dare pick another.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on March 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You see carry pain like /would my own child, Tend to it, nurture it, Embrace it and watch it bloom. They say I'm beautiful but terribly sad, And tell them there's nothing beautiful about heartbreak, Nor any poetry romantic enough to make so. so. Pain is ugly, heartbreak is ugly, But the healing that follows, That's where the beauty lies.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on March 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'There's an old story tell myself, Of how in the late 19th century,a nameless girl had drowned in the River Seine at the age of sixteen. L'inconnue de la Seine they had called her The Unknown woman of the Seine. Even in death she looked so beautiful That they made a cast of her face, A face that would then take the world by storm and half century later, form the model mannequin to learn and teach resuscitation, To save countless lives.'.

node.text:
Of Love that tastes like Claustrophobia [Swipe/Scroll to Read] :
🔹
@_de_wang_ said write a poem using Love, Nature and Claustrophobia. And obviously I had to ⬇️
🔹
There's an old cabin we called our
holiday home but it's been a while 
since I took a break or felt at home. 
I sit at the kitchen table and
Think about how it all feels smaller now;
Four walls held more space 
even with the two of us,
when I wasn't suffocating 
in your absence and the 
solitude of my own thoughts. 

Cradled within an army of red pines, 
there runs a crystal brook on the 
east side of my log laden walls.
It whispers to me all things secret, 
all things buried, 
all things that should have remained so.
And I listen in silence to the march of the dead that comes to haunt me under the envelop of a harsh silver moon. 

Come morning, the sun rises only to glint off a now sullen stream to set my porch on fire.
I think of how she called me her sunflower,
As I now stand half withered in the embrace of her memories. 
They said to love her was like playing 
with fire and I was much too reckless.
This house is no longer a home, 
This house is burning, 
There is smoke,
But what's smoke to a man slowly being choked by the walls of his own abode. 

Morningbirds lament the loss of love, 
Perched upon broken promises, 
As wild animals retreat from the rage 
That swallows what was once home.
And I'm left alone, 
Slow dancing with a ghost 
To cinder symphonies
In a burning room that grows smaller,
With every ashen breath I take. 

// Love closes in on me, 
Since the day you walked out the door. 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
Yuki ❄️ : 

Someone recently asked me
what it is about winter 
that I like so much.
And I wanted to say things like 
Christmas and snow,
warm blankets and hot chocolate.
But all that really came out of 
my mouth was how it 
reminded me of you. 

I am a winter's child 
in that I love it so,
Or maybe I have 
no choice in the matter. 
How do I tell them that
Everything I liked about winter,
Are also the same things I hate; 
That everything I loved about you 
Are also things that made me break. 

I'm a lover stuck in a snowglobe, 
Waiting for snowfall but not before 
You shake my world and 
Turn it upside down
To give me what I wanted 
But only for a short while 
Before you leave me on the table, 
And the snow settles beneath my feet. 

And I said loving you was like
Trying to love the snow,
Which is to say, 
You can only catch fragments
of it before it settles and 
brings you to your knees; 
You can only lay in it for so long 
before you freeze where you sleep. 

There's a warmth I cannot seem to reach,
Like a glass veil that sits between us 
On cold winter nights. 
They say love, 
like life is bittersweet, 
But lately everytime 
you talk of sweet love, 
I'm left feeling bitter cold. 

And so I stood knee deep 
in endless white frosted sheets 
under the mistletoe
catching snowflakes beneath
the winter moon, waiting for you
only to watch them melt 
and slip away between my fingers. 

So when I'm asked why 
I like winter,
I'm reminded of you,
But even more so, 
Of the warmth in my own hands, 
That kept me from freezing.
.
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
[Swipe To Read] : 
🔹
I'm a sucker for old stories and @annabelle_ernest gave me one that I had to write with, and so here we are. 
Titanic, but not as we know it, not the one that won awards. 
Leaving the actual story below: 

Charles John Joughin was an English-American chef, known as being the chief baker aboard the RMS Titanic. He survived the ship's sinking, and became notable for having survived in the frigid water for an exceptionally long time. 

When the ship hit an iceberg, Joughin was off-duty and in his bunk.
He sent his thirteen men up to the boat deck with provisions to the lifeboats: four loaves of bread apiece, about forty pounds of bread each. 
He joined Chief Officer Henry Wilde by Lifeboat 10 and helped with stewards and other seamen, the ladies and children through to the lifeboat, although, after a while, the women on deck ran away from the boat saying they were safer aboard the Titanic. He then went on to A Deck and forcibly brought up women and children, throwing them into the lifeboat.
Although he was assigned as captain, he did not board; it was already being manned by two sailors and a steward. He went below instead, and "had a drop of liqueur" (a tumbler half-full of liqueur, as he went on to specify) in his quarters. 

He climbed to the starboard side of the poop deck, getting hold of the safety rail so that he was on the outside of the ship as it went down by the head. As the ship finally sank, he rode it down as if it were an elevator, not getting his head under the water (in his words, his head "may have been wetted, but no more"). He was, thus, the last survivor to leave the RMS Titanic.
According to his own testimony, he kept paddling and treading water for about two hours. He admitted to hardly feeling the cold, thanks to the alcohol he had imbibed.
Seeing the upturned Collapsible B, he swam towards it only to find it with no space for him, 
A man recognized him and held his hand. Joughin waited with his feet and legs still in the water till another lifeboat appeared where he stayed till he was taken into RMS Carpathia that came to their rescue. 

He was rescued from the sea with only swollen feet.
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021 tagging @silverleafpoetry, @scribblersword, @globalagepoetry, @globalagetyro, @globalagecaption, and @brownhourpoetry. May be an image of text that says 'Of Stories Less Talked About Sunset dreams come knocking on my window as sit in the confines of my four walls revisiting old memories braised in liquor. It's all a blur but the feelings- they linger in the spaces between my eyelids, just long enough to be washed away by tears that no longer flow but are swallowed.'.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021 tagging @poetsanonymousink, @poetsgrid, @thewriteristichutofficial, and @wovenverses. May be an image of text that says 'I'm a man who loves and does so deeply but am hardly perfect, SO put love in places it never belonged for it to only mould itself into sorrow that latches onto me like ghoul that has made a home within the attics of my shoulder. It weighs heavy and walk with a little tilt in my stature but am reminded of how I've learnt to carry on despite it, And think, maybe it's okay to be this way.'.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021 tagging @thewritingspook, @heartofquill, and @_inkverse. May be an image of text that says 'They say I'm a man who is too nice for my own good, / was told kindness will part raging oceans for me should choose it, but only long enough for me to cross it. Stay and I'll drown, Stay and the oceans will swallow me whole They say am but man who can only make his way in this world, not change its nature. I tried once, and nearly drowned.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I'm reminded of story once told to me, A story left in the shadows of an epic tale of romance. A story about the chief baker aboard the RMS Titanic, Charles John Joughin They say when the iceberg hit the ship, he sent his men to deck with forty pounds of bread each provisions for the lifeboat, while he helped passengers escape along with other crewmates. He then proceeded to his quarters to drink away his last moments before he rode the ship down by the safety rails into the frigid sea; the last Survivor to leave the ship.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says '/ think of how when /say Titanic, people talk aou love and loss and heartbreak but never about kindness or duty or sacrifice. Of how some stories are hardly ever told because another takes its place.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'sit in my chair by the window as think about reasons why /nearly drowned yet remain unchanged, And remember how it wouldn' t be a couple of hours before Joughin would find lifeboat with enough space for him to be pulled out of the icy clutches of the sea that threatened to pull him under. He admitted to hardly ever feeling cold because the liquor kept him warm, And he was rescued from sea, with naught but swollen feet.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says '/ think about how a man prepared to die had survived because he chose to stay. pour myself another glass, And hope, one day I'll learn to swim the same should the oceans collapse again, and find myself drowning. / think about how the things presumed to be bad for me could one day save my life, / think about how maybe kindness would find t's way back to me in time.'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says '// Kindness deserves to be talked about, Kindness deserves to stay. -s.a'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 20, 2021. May be an image of grass, cloud, nature, tree and twilight.

node.text:
[Swipe/Scroll to Read.] 
🔹
Yakusoku (Promise) - 

I think about death often, 
For a guy who found a girl with 
more life than life ever gave him.
She says she's the same, 
And I think maybe death lingers 
Where life thrives unbound. 

There's a village on the far side of the mountains, in a distant country, 
Where time does not exist.
Snow capped peaks breathe wisps
of green and violet into the night sky,
Where winter eagles dance 
To the cry of the wind, 
And the moon watches eagerly, 
While the stars gossip about the
Sun's imminent return. 

We talk about all the things we don't know;
We choose to break down,
Under the wings of a cherry blossom, 
In a different city. 
She says she's never seen snow, 
And I say I've never watched the stars. 
So we make promises to be kept in a 
place where time is fiction, 
To write stories of our own. 
She'd teach me how Orion has three sisters that stands between the two brothers -
Betelgeuse and Rigel, lest they go to war.
And I'd help her build castles out of snow, 
While I whisper poetry into her ears, 
Of how even the stars 
dare not stand between us;
And we piece ourselves together, 
For all the times we've fallen apart. 

There's a lake that lies at the foot of the mountain, untouched, untarnished, 
She says this is it - her final resting place,
And I see love in her eyes, 
even when we she talks of death, 
And I think maybe this is what a life 
Worth living looks like. 

I tell her I wish to be buried under a tree,
By the mountains, overlooking the sea,
And she says maybe she'd come find me,
Should she live long enough.
I think about death so often for a man 
Who found a reason to live, 
My eyes are full of life,
Even when I talk of death.
You ask me why, 
And I tell you there's a girl 
who promised to come visit
Me under the cherry blossom,
To read me poems until the sun sets 
Till we find each other again,
In a place where time stands still. 

// Love; 
As in life, so in death. 
.
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
[Swipe/Scroll To Read] 
🔹
An Ode to the Poems I Buried - 

Stillborn dreams lay beneath my fingernails from the day I scratched my tongue to dig out words that hadn't fully formed yet. 
I mourn half painted sunrises held in the palms of faceless lovers with every forlorn touch,
To leave the scent of sorrow on the things I carry. 

My fingers crack under the weight of miscarried love, I can barely fold them. 
Doctors show me white shadows on black films and call it calcification,
All I see are gravestones that fill joint spaces, so much so that I can no longer grasp the love I once held so dearly. 

I birthed hope and sorrow on the same day and called them twins. They said one is unlike the other even though they were just minutes apart -
Like Twilight and Dusk, though I could hardly ever tell; 
I buried them silently with the night.
I'm a failed parent with sunset bruises, who lacked the courage to tell my children it wasn't their fault that they never saw the break of dawn. 

There are cuts on my tongue yet I taste no blood, 
But metaphors lay waste in the cradle of wounds that is my mouth.
I've got fallen stars for teeth and a uvula blood moon pulling the tides on this ocean of gore that I swallow to tell you
I know what the universe tastes like. 

Yet if I were asked to describe it, 
I would have half finished sunrises and loveless faces that split my heart in two to give murmurs of dead poems that flow within these veins,
for a chance 
To breathe again. 
.
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
[Scroll/Swipe to Read] 
🔻
Prompts : 
1. Write a piece on healing (@poetrybykavya #promptsbykavya)
2. Beauty lives in freckles and scars (@crimson.soul #crimsonprompts) 
3. I fall like pieces falling into place
(@notexactlyawriter #neawprompts)
🔻
I've been staring at my fingers for a while now, there's a cut on my left thumb from a week ago when I handled a broken vase - broken yet beautiful I told myself till it cut me and I cussed under my breath and I thought how I was neither whole nor beautiful. 
I think about how vases have jagged ends we keep on display till we decide it needs to be put together with gold like it's a metaphor for our lives while all we really do is cover up our serrated skin in the hopes that we do not cut another. 

I remember seeing the blood that dripped from my hand and thinking how it was a pretty shade of red - this thing that courses inside my veins is pretty so I hurry to stop myself from bleeding in fear that I may lose too much of it. 
This is what I do, I hold onto parts of me with such fervour lest I lose myself in an attempt to feel sightly in someone else's eyes, 
They say give and you shall receive so
I've given and given and given and yet,
I've only lost. 

The wound is all but fully healed now, the silver shimmer of new skin that grows over old cuts will leave a scar that will tell a story should I choose to say it. 
There is no gold here, there is no Midas touch that makes me whole but I fall like pieces falling into place,
Put back together 
Over
And over 
And over again. 

Someone once told me that beauty lives in freckles and scars
I've got no freckles but I've got scars on my fingers 
so I pen poetry portraying pigments on the face of a pretty girl with brown eyes in the hopes that it makes me half as beautiful if nothing else. 
I am a storyteller, I don't need much except my words and your attention to feel alive so I write 
about broken vases put together with gold 
about cut hands and pretty shades of red 
about healing fingers and scars forged in silver 
about pretty girls and eyes dipped in chocolate brown.

(Contd in comments.) 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021 tagging @saxophonestories_. May be an image of outdoors and tree.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021 tagging @poetrybykavya, @notexactlyawriter, and @crimsoned.babble. May be an image of text that says 'On Healing: I've been staring at my fingers for a while now, there's a cut on my left thumb from a week ago when handled a broken vase- broken yet beautiful told myself till it cut me and cussed under my breath and thought how/ was neither whole nor beautiful. think about how vases have jagged ends we keep on display till we decide it needs to be put together with gold like it's a metaphor for our lives while all we really do is cover up our serrated skin in the hopes that we do not cut another.'.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021 tagging @silverleafpoetry, @scribblersword, @globalagepoetry, @globalagecaption, and @wovenverses. May be an image of text that says '/remember seeing the blood that dripped from my hand and thinking how it was a pretty shade of red this thing that courses inside my veins is pretty so hurry to stop myself from bleeding in fear that may lose too much of it. This is what do, hold onto parts of me with such fervour lest lose myself in an attempt to feel sightly in someone else's eyes, They say give and you shall receive so I've given and given and given and yet, I've only lost.'.

Photo shared by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021 tagging @poetsanonymousink, @heartofquill, @brownhourpoetry, and @_inkverse. May be an image of text that says 'The wound is all but fully healed now, the silver shimmer of new skin that grows over old cuts will leave a scar that will tell a story should choose to say it. There is no gold here, there is no Midas touch that makes me whole but fall like pieces falling into place, Put back together Over And over And over again.'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I've been staring at my fingers for a while now, there are lines that run along my fingertips that tell my story, an imprint of mounds and trenches that leave with every touch to tell you I'm here, exist, belong. And everytime turn to the stars for inspiration They remind me there are more stories within my fingers than will ever need, Stories have healed enough to tell. -s.a'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 12, 2021.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 06, 2021. May be an image of tree and outdoors.

node.text:
[Swipe/Scroll to Read] :

In hindsight, I probably should have put this up on my birthday, but oh well. 

@_selcouthsouls asked me to write a poem that's "All lies and no Truth." and so I did. 
Except for the part where there's a boy who likes flowers, that's me, I like flowers. 

Also special thanks to my cuties @bhargavi_vijayanandam
and @ashita_malpani who sent me my favourite flowers for my birthday. [Also the panda cactus in the background] , Lots of love 🤍
🔸

A boy who loved flowers : 

I lost my older brother when I was ten to a mindless accident I couldn't fully comprehend but I remember wishing I had a sister instead because mother kept saying boys are too reckless while she emptied a river into my hands I was too young to hold.
She said the good ones are always taken too soon from us. 

"Boys are too reckless"; 
I was born a boy and mother called me her favourite,
And I kept thinking if I'd be taken sooner than I wanted.
So I ran away from home during the quiet stolen hours of the night till my parents found me in a chapel on my knees praying in a pool of my own tears,
Asking God if it'd be okay to be a good boy and want to live a little longer. 

Father carried me home that night while my mother told me that God wouldn't do for me what I won't do for myself, 
I lost my brother and my faith on the same day. 

It's my birthday today and I'm 21 now but mother dotes on me like I'm ten still, while my father sits on his favourite chair reading yesterday's paper. 
Because to accept today's date means to acknowledge me a grown man and neither of us are ready to see a boy who outgrew his brother.
So we sit across each other in silence till he passes me the key to a car and said "It's yours, be safe, don't be too reckless." 

It's my birthday and I sit in my car with my hands on the wheel and my heart on my sleeve, mourning every year I've lived. 
I've got my foot on the gas and I think how easy it'd be to wrap this car around a tree that's a block away. 

(Contd. In comments) 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

May be an image of text that says 'It takes me a while before realise the little boy from next door is at my window watching me cry so force a smile and ask him if he needed something, He shakes his head and hands me a flower and says, "You looked sad and thought you' like a pretty one.' Maybe for a minute stopped mourning, And my smile didn' t feel as forced.'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on February 06, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
[Scroll/Swipe to Read] :
🔸
Somewhere in this City - 

Somewhere in this city, a mother tended to her crying child with a scraped knee from a tussle with an inconsiderate stretch of rough tar; 
The Mother beat the ground as punishment,
And kissed his leg for the pain. 
The child learned two things that day -
One, the world is tough, but his mother is tougher.
And two, the world was better off soft, like his mother's kiss. 

Somewhere in this city, a heartbroken lover salts her dinner with her tears, over a heartless man who left her. 
One glass of wine becomes two, 
two glasses become four,
Till she falls asleep in her own embrace under the warmth she bought in a bottle. 
She wakes to the gentle kiss of a filtered sun that flits through her curtains and she thinks of two things - 
One, life is cruel but not as cruel as love. 
And two, life would be better if love was gentle, like the morning sun. 

Somewhere in this city, a man in blue shorts tends to stray pups lying limp on the sidewalk, having barely survived the frigid night. 
A woman steps out of her building to throw away the previous nights' tear crusted dinner gone cold,
Only to be asked by the man if she'd let him have it, to feed the dogs. 
She hands him the food and asks if she could join, 
He smiles as bright as the sun before he says he'd love that,
There's a kindness in his voice that's hard to come by.
She asks him why he cares as much for strays on a random street, 
He scratches an old scar on his knee before he says "My mother taught me two things as a child - that the world is tough and I need to be tougher, but that the world is better off soft if I could help it."
And she tells him how she woke up thinking life was cruel, 
But right now, it seems a lot kinder. 

Somewhere in this city, 
The morning sun came with the promise of a new day with warm breaths,
The world is softer, 
Love is a little more gentle, 
And life was a whole lot better. 
.
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
[Swipe to Read] : 
🔸
Posting the second version based off the same prompts and this time it's a love poem. 
Also leaving more relevant facts here - 

1. About three in four of India’s districts are hotspots of extreme climate events such as cyclones, floods, drought, heat and cold waves, according to a study by the Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW), a research agency.

2. In 2019, India witnessed 16 extreme flood events, which affected 151 districts. The study found that over 9.7 crore (97 million) people are currently exposed to extreme floods in India. Six of India’s eight most flood-prone districts in the last decade — Barpeta, Darrang, Dhemaji, Goalpara, Golaghat, Sivasagar — are in Assam. The last 50 years also recorded a 12-fold surge in the number of associated cyclonic events such as extreme rainfall, floods, and thunderstorms. 

3. The frequency, intensity, and unpredictability of these extreme events have risen in recent decades – while India witnessed 250 extreme climate events in 35 years between 1970 and 2005, it recorded 310 such weather events in only 15 years since then, the study has pointed out. The study also found a shift in the pattern of extreme climate events such as flood-prone areas becoming drought-prone and vice-versa in over 40% of districts. 

*Refer to previous take for the rest. 
Hope you like it :) 🌻
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of nature, coast, beach, sky and ocean.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The world in my hands /On Unrequited Love: The world is breaking in the middle of my palms which is to say I've been holding my heart out for you but so far all that's left of us are mistakes turned fault lines running on these red walls that still beats to your name. I'd have moved heaven and earth for you but all that's changed are these tectonic plates you've pushed out of place; I've got tremors in my hands from carrying a heart that trembles frantically at the sound of your voice.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The world is moulding itself in my grasp which is to say I've changed and I've changed for you but there's only so far / can go before my heart is no longer a heart and can barely recognise myself. Gaia theory says that Earth is a living breathing organism that adapts to help life thrive. But a mere 0.6°C rise in temperature in the last 100 years results in catastrophic climate, And / wonder how much longer have before adapting to you means my own extinction.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The world is bleeding through my fingers which is to say/ would dedicate my entire life to you but there's only so much / can bleed before I'm bled dry. There's a warm westerly wind which arises from the Pacific called the Chinook that is so dry, it vapourises snow on contact. / can't help but think that this love I carry as deep as the ocean has been left out to dry, that I'm afraid the next person I touch will at best, turn to dust.'.

Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You see, I'm a man of science but all the research do hardly explains this pit that forms in my stomach like the centre of a storm waiting to arrive only to pull me apart. The last 50 years recorded a 12 fold surge in associated cyclone events like thunderstorms, extreme rainfall and floods. Now, three out of four districts in india are hotspots of extreme weather climate. And don't know how to tell you that/ could move to the safest one and you'd still hit me like a fucking hurricane.'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says '// The world is in my hands, You held them as you liked, And now it's breaking. -s.a'.
Photo by Shaaz Ahmed on January 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, food, ocean and sky.

node.text:
[Swipe/Scroll to Read] 
🔸 
Prompt by @silverleafpoetry : Write a poem inspired by "The pain I don't say out loud builds a home inside me."
#silverleafcontest 
🔸
Of Homes With Closed Doors : 

I was a little boy taught not to lie because dishonesty isn't tolerated in a household built on unspoken truths and whitewashed pretences.
My father like his father before him, has been taught that strength lies in silent sufferings and muted miseries because it is unbecoming of a man to raise his voice if not to fight. 

I was a little boy mistaken for a girl 
when I was 9, because I cried that day and 
mother said, "Hush little child, how are you
to become a man if you can't hold back tears, have you ever seen your father cry? 
You have much to learn." 
So I swallowed my tears to water the pain
That I buried beneath my throat
And watched it take root. 

I am a man now, six and twenty years old, 
There's a wilting garden that lays
beneath my ribs, and everytime I'm asked how I feel, I pick dead flowers from between my teeth and weave a wreath I hang at the
door to my chest. 

I had much to learn and so I did, 
on blackboards with white chalks
I wrote white lies to paint bright smiles; 
And on white sheets with black ink
I wrote dark secrets to hide sullen cries. 

I was a little boy taught to build walls 
and no windows, so I burnt chalks to make
lime, and cement my lies within my bones.
"Be a fortress, stand tall", said my father;
But father, a fortress that isn't a home first, is just a prison. 

Now I'm a man fully grown with four limbs for four walls, no windows and a closed door, watering dead plants in the hope that one day, 
sunlight will find me through the door I haven't learnt to open yet. 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords

node.text:
[Swipe To Read] 
🔸
I wrote another fact based poem thanks to @_de_wang_ , 
And the prompt - "Start a poem with The world is breaking in the middle of my palms." by @_selcouthsouls . 

Originally wrote yet another love poem which was pointed out and suggested that I try something different so I ended up with this.
 [ I will put that up as well in due time, let me know in the comments if I should. ] 
As I write this I'm aware how little and how much more I need to do to make our lives more sustainable. 

Leaving the relevant facts here for more clarity - 

1. Earth is a perfect planet for life but, according to Gaia theory, this is no coincidence. From the moment life first appeared on Earth it has worked hard to make Earth a more comfortable place to live. Gaia theory suggests that the Earth and its natural cycles can be thought of like a living organism. When one natural cycle starts to go out of kilter other cycles work to bring it back, continually optimising the conditions for life on Earth. 
Named after the Greek Earth goddess, Gaia, the theory was developed in the 1960s by scientist Dr James Lovelock.

2. In the western U.S., there's a wind called the Chinook, or "snow eater," that vaporizes snow before it even has a chance to melt.
Chinook winds are westerlies from the Pacific whose moisture gets wrung out as it passes over the Rocky Mountains. Once these winds come down onto the high plains, the air is so dry that when it hits a snowpack, the frozen water evaporates, going directly from the ice to vapor and bypassing the liquid phase entirely.

3. The hottest decade on record is coming to a close, with the last five years being the hottest since 1880. 2020 is just two-hundredths of a degree cooler than 2016, the hottest year ever recorded. The Earth is nearly 2 degrees Fahrenheit warmer now than it was in the 20th century, and greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere are still rising.

4.The last 50 years also recorded a 12-fold surge in the number of associated cyclonic events such as extreme rainfall, floods, and thunderstorms. 
.
.
#ofwheelsandwords
